definition.Noun: A messenger bringing news, or a sign that something is about to happen.
definition.Verb: To announce or signal the arrival of something.

examples: The town crier acted as a herald, announcing the arrival of the king.
The blooming flowers are a herald of spring.
The new technology heralds a significant advancement in medicine.
The discovery of gold heralded a new era of prosperity for the region.

definition.Noun: A thorough examination and repair.
definition.Verb: To take apart in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.

examples: The car needs a complete overhaul.
The company decided to overhaul its operational procedures.
After years of neglect, the building was overhauled to meet current safety standards.

definition.Noun: A large number or quantity.
definition.Verb: To turn or slide violently or uncontrollably.

examples: She has a slew of books on her reading list.
The car slewed to the side of the road.
He slewed the boat around to face the wind.

definition.Verb: To change direction or position.
definition.Adjective: Not straight or level.
definition.Noun: An oblique angle; a slant.

examples: The data may be skewed by the small sample size.
The picture on the wall was slightly skew.
There is a noticeable skew in the distribution of the results.

definition.Adjective: Exciting, lively, or trendy.

examples: The new restaurant is very buzzy and popular.
The tech startup scene is quite buzzy right now.

definition.Adjective: Extremely serious or urgent.

examples: The country is in dire need of food aid.
The situation became dire when the storm hit.

definition.Noun: A wind blowing directly against the course of movement.
A situation or condition that makes progress difficult.

examples: The cyclists struggled against a strong headwind.
The company faced significant headwinds in the market.

translation: 严酷的, 令人沮丧的

definition.Adjective: Unpleasant or shocking to see or think about; serious or gloomy.

examples: The news of the disaster was grim.
He looked at her with a grim expression.

definition.Verb: To give up one's office or position.

examples: She decided to resign from her position as CEO.
After the scandal, he had no choice but to resign.

definition.Adjective: Incapable of producing any useful result; pointless.

examples: Their efforts to save the company were futile.
It was futile to continue the argument.

definition.Adjective: Inborn; natural; existing in one from birth.

examples: He has an innate talent for music.
The ability to speak is an innate human characteristic.

definition.Noun: A plan or purpose; something that one intends to do.
definition.Adjective: Determined or resolved to do something.

examples: His intent was to improve the company's performance.
She looked at him with an intent expression.

translation: 使迷恋, 使冲昏头脑

definition.Verb: To inspire or possess with a foolish or unreasonable passion or love, often to the point of being irrational.

examples: He was completely infatuated with her beauty.
The young artist became infatuated with fame.

definition.Verb: To break suddenly into many small pieces.

examples: The glass vase fell and shattered into a thousand pieces.
The news shattered her hopes.

definition.Noun: Danger of loss, harm, or failure.

examples: The company's future is in jeopardy.
He was in jeopardy of losing his job.

definition.Adjective: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse.

examples: The ladder was in a precarious position.
She made a precarious living as a freelance writer.

definition.Noun: A small strip or amount of something.
definition.Verb: To tear or cut into small pieces.

examples: He tore the letter into shreds.
I don't have a shred of doubt about it.

definition.Adjective: Involving repetition or iteration.

examples: The process is iterative and will be refined over time.
An iterative approach was used to improve the design.

definition.Adjective: Not real or true; imaginary or fabricated.

examples: The characters in the book are entirely fictitious.
She gave a fictitious name to the police.

definition.Noun: The dark shape and outline of someone or something visible against a lighter background.

examples: The silhouette of the mountains was visible against the evening sky.
She could see his silhouette through the curtain.

definition.Verb: To make less severe, serious, or painful.

examples: Steps were taken to mitigate the effects of the crisis.
They tried to mitigate the risks associated with the project.

definition.Noun: A state or period of uncontrolled excitement or wild behavior.

examples: The crowd was in a frenzy over the band's performance.
She worked herself into a frenzy trying to finish the project.

definition.Verb: To make something physically stronger or more solid; to combine into a single more effective or coherent whole.

examples: The company consolidated its position in the market.
They decided to consolidate all their resources.

definition.Noun: A point or line common to lines or surfaces that intersect.

examples: The accident happened at a busy intersection.
There's a traffic light at the intersection of two main roads.

definition.Verb: To make or become rotten; to break down into simpler components.

examples: The leaves decomposed into compost over time.
Organic waste will decompose quickly in a compost bin.

definition.Noun: The part of the body containing the digestive organs; the belly.

examples: He felt a sharp pain in his abdomen.
The abdomen houses many vital organs.

translation: 锯齿状的, 不规则的

definition.Adjective: Having rough, sharp points protruding.

examples: The jagged rocks made it difficult to climb.
She cut her hand on the jagged edge of the metal.

definition.Noun: A place where bodies are kept, especially to be identified or prepared for burial.

examples: The hospital's mortuary is located in the basement.
The funeral home has a small mortuary.

definition.Adjective: Savagely fierce, cruel, or violent.

examples: The ferocious lion attacked its prey.
The storm was ferocious, causing widespread damage.

definition.Verb: To cut open and remove the internal organs of.

examples: The hunter disemboweled the deer after the kill.
In ancient times, disembowelment was a form of execution.

definition.Noun: A feeling of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder.
definition.Verb: To inspire with awe.

examples: The sight of the Grand Canyon filled me with awe.
She was awed by the sheer scale of the project.

definition.Noun: An area of relatively level high ground; a state of little or no change following a period of activity or progress.

examples: The hikers reached the plateau by midday.
Her career has reached a plateau.

translation: 田园诗般的, 悠闲的

definition.Adjective: Extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.

examples: They enjoyed an idyllic vacation on a remote island.
The village was an idyllic place to grow up.

translation: 首要的, 支配一切的, 包罗万象的

definition.Adjective: Comprehensive or all-embracing; having an effect on or influence over all aspects of something.

examples: The overarching theme of the novel is the struggle for power.
Their overarching goal is to improve the quality of education.

translation: 黑手党, 秘密犯罪组织

definition.Noun: A secret criminal organization operating mainly in Italy and the U.S., involved in illegal activities such as drug trafficking, extortion, and racketeering.

examples: The police have been cracking down on the mafia's activities in the city.
He was suspected of having ties to the mafia.

definition.Verb: To make more beautiful or attractive by adding something decorative.

examples: They adorned the hall with flowers for the wedding.
Her dress was adorned with delicate lace and beads.

definition.Verb: To grasp or hold tightly.
definition.Noun: A mechanism in a vehicle that allows the engine to connect and disconnect from the transmission; also, a tight grip or hold.

examples: She clutched her bag as she walked through the crowded street.
The car's clutch needs to be replaced because it's slipping.

definition.Verb: To indicate or suggest something that will happen in the future.

examples: The dark clouds foreshadowed the coming storm.
Her early interest in biology foreshadowed her future career as a scientist.

definition.Verb: To bring back to life; to revive or restore something that had been forgotten, abandoned, or lost.

examples: The scientists are trying to resurrect extinct species through genetic engineering.
The company plans to resurrect the old brand to appeal to nostalgic consumers.

definition.Verb: To surprise or frighten someone suddenly, causing them to make a quick movement.

examples: The sudden loud noise startled the children.
She was startled by his unexpected appearance at the door.

definition.Verb: To treat a sacred place or thing with violent disrespect; to violate the sanctity of something.

examples: Vandals desecrated the ancient tomb by spray-painting graffiti on its walls.
The protesters were accused of desecrating the national flag.

definition.Verb: To inspire or permeate with a feeling or quality.

examples: The teacher tried to imbue her students with a love of learning.
His speeches imbue the audience with hope and optimism.

definition.Verb: To cause (something unpleasant or painful) to be suffered by someone or something; to impose.

examples: The boxer inflicted a crushing defeat on his opponent.
The storm inflicted severe damage on the coastal town.

translation: 忙碌, 奋力争取, 诈骗

Verb: To move or work energetically and rapidly.
To push or force someone to move hurriedly or unceremoniously.
To obtain by forceful action or persuasion, often in a deceitful or fraudulent way.
Noun: A deceitful or fraudulent scheme, especially in business or social contexts.

examples: She hustled to get the job done before the deadline.
The street vendor hustled tourists into buying fake souvenirs.
The hustle and bustle of the city can be overwhelming.
He was caught up in a hustle that cost him thousands of dollars.

translation: 表达清晰的, 清楚表达

definition.Adjective: Able to express ideas and feelings clearly and effectively in speech or writing.
definition.Verb: To express (an idea or feeling) fluently and coherently.

examples: She is a highly articulate speaker.
He was able to articulate his thoughts clearly during the meeting.

Noun: A sudden, involuntary contraction of the diaphragm and muscles of the chest, causing a characteristic sound.
A temporary or minor problem or setback.
definition.Verb: To make a hiccuping sound or action.

examples: She had a bad case of the hiccups after drinking soda.
There was a small hiccup in the project's progress, but it's back on track now.

definition.Noun: A person employed to drive a private or hired car.
definition.Verb: To drive (someone) in a vehicle, typically as a chauffeur.

examples: The company hired a chauffeur to drive their executives to meetings.
She was chauffeured to the event in a luxury car.

definition.Verb: To spend money freely or extravagantly.
definition.Noun: An act of spending money freely or extravagantly.

examples: She decided to splurge on a new designer handbag.
Their shopping trip turned into a splurge of spending on luxury items.

translation: 骤降, 跳入, 投入

Verb: To jump or dive quickly and energetically.
Noun: A sudden decrease in value or amount.

examples: He took a deep breath and plunged into the water.
The stock market plunged after the news of the financial crisis.
The road plunges down the hillside.

definition.Noun: A social or cultural prohibition or restriction on a particular practice or behavior.
definition.Adjective: Prohibited or restricted by social custom.

examples: Discussing religion can be a taboo subject in some cultures.
It is taboo to talk about money in certain social settings.

definition.Phrase: An informal command telling someone to stop doing something, typically something annoying or inappropriate.

examples: The teacher told the students to knock it off when they were talking during class.
Hey, knock it off! That's really annoying.

definition.Verb: To refrain from insisting on or using a right or claim; to voluntarily give up something, such as a right or a requirement.

examples: The company decided to waive the late fee for the customer.
He waived his right to a lawyer and chose to represent himself in court.

definition.Adjective: Flexible and supple; capable of being bent or moved easily.
definition.Verb: To make something or someone more flexible or agile, typically through stretching exercises.

examples: Dancers must be limber to perform their routines with ease.
She did yoga every morning to stay limber.
He limbered up before the race by doing some stretches.

definition.Verb: To force or oblige (someone) to do something; to bring about by force.

examples: The court order compelled him to reveal the source of his information.
Her curiosity compelled her to investigate further.

definition.Noun: A flat piece hinged vertically near the stern of a boat or ship for steering.

examples: The sailor adjusted the rudder to change the boat's direction.
The ship lost control when its rudder was damaged in the storm.

definition.Verb: 1. To move or cause to move slowly back and forth or from side to side. 2. To influence or control, especially by winning favor.
definition.Noun: The action or an instance of swaying; controlling influence.

examples: The trees swayed in the strong wind.
His emotional speech swayed many voters to his side.
The politician held considerable sway over public opinion.

definition.Noun phrase: The desire to experience pleasure or fulfillment without delay or deferment; the need to receive something or to feel a positive emotion right away.

examples: Social media often caters to our desire for immediate gratification.
Learning to delay immediate gratification is an important part of personal growth.

definition.Adjective: Lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
definition.Noun: A person who stays or works in a place for a short time only.

examples: The pain was transient and soon faded away.
Many transients seek temporary shelter in the city during winter months.

definition.Verb: 1. To enclose (something) in or as if in a capsule. 2. To express the essential features of (something) succinctly.

examples: The new technology encapsulates the drug in a polymer coating for slow release.
Her speech perfectly encapsulated the mood of the nation.

definition.Adjective: Acting in anticipation of future problems, needs, or changes.

examples: She is proactive in addressing potential issues before they become problems.
A proactive approach to health involves regular exercise and a balanced diet.

definition.Adjective: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.

examples: She was indifferent to the outcome of the game.
The manager seemed indifferent to the complaints of his employees.

definition.Verb: To take part in an activity in a casual or superficial way.

examples: She likes to dabble in painting, though she's not a professional artist.
He dabbled in photography before finding his true passion in writing.

translation: 令人沮丧的，使人灰心的

definition.Adjective: Causing a loss of hope or enthusiasm; discouraging.

examples: It was disheartening to see how much damage the storm had caused.
The constant rejections were disheartening, but she didn't give up on her dream.

definition.Adjective: Contrary to reason or common sense; utterly absurd or ridiculous.

examples: The idea that aliens built the pyramids is preposterous.
It's preposterous to suggest that we should give up all modern conveniences.

translation: 敲诈, 欺骗, 骗人的东西

definition.Noun: Something that is not worth what you pay for it; a scam or unfair overcharge.

examples: The price they charged for the service was a total rip-off.
That concert was a rip-off; the band only played for 30 minutes.

definition.Noun: Goods that are bought and sold, especially in retail.
definition.Verb: To promote the sale of goods, especially through advertising or other marketing strategies.

examples: The store offers a wide variety of merchandise, from clothing to electronics.
They plan to merchandise the new product line heavily this holiday season.

definition.Noun: Small items or miscellaneous objects that are usually not of much value or importance.

examples: She spent the weekend sorting through odds and ends in the attic.
The drawer was filled with odds and ends like paper clips and old batteries.

definition.Adjective: Paid in advance or at the beginning.
definition.Adverb: In an open and honest way.

examples: The company requires an upfront payment before starting the project.
He was upfront about his intentions from the start.

definition.Verb: To push someone or something in a rough or careless way.

examples: He shoved the door open and walked in.
She gave him a shove to get him out of the way.

definition.Verb: To breathe in air, gas, smoke, etc.

examples: She inhaled deeply before starting her speech.
He accidentally inhaled some smoke from the fire.

definition.Verb:
To waste (something, especially money or time) in a reckless and foolish manner.
"Squander" is a strong verb that implies not just using something up, but wasting it in a particularly careless or foolish way. It's often used in contexts related to:

Financial resources: Spending money recklessly or on unnecessary things.
Time: Using time ineffectively or on trivial matters.
Opportunities: Failing to take advantage of favorable circumstances.
Talents or abilities: Not making good use of one's skills or potential.

The word carries a negative connotation and often implies regret or criticism for the wasteful action.

examples: He squandered his inheritance on luxury cars and expensive holidays.
Don't squander this opportunity; it may not come again.

definition.Adjective: Not having any serious purpose or value; not serious in content, attitude, or behavior.

examples: She dismissed his frivolous comments and focused on the important issues.
The court deemed the lawsuit frivolous and threw it out.
further_explanation:
The term 'frivolous' is often used to describe actions, attitudes, or things that lack seriousness or importance. It can be applied in various contexts:
1. In everyday language: To describe silly or pointless activities or concerns.
2. In legal contexts: Referring to lawsuits or legal motions that lack any merit or are filed without sufficient grounds.
3. In spending: Describing unnecessary or extravagant purchases.
4. In behavior: Characterizing someone who doesn't take important matters seriously.
The word generally carries a negative connotation, implying that something or someone is not worth taking seriously.

definition.Verb: 1. To regain (something lost, especially money); to recuperate. 2. To compensate for (a loss or expense).

examples: The company hopes to recoup its investment within five years.
She worked overtime to recoup the time she lost while on vacation.
further_explanation:
The word 'recoup' is often used in financial contexts, but it can apply to various situations where something is being recovered or compensated for:
1. Business: Companies often talk about recouping costs or investments.
2. Personal finance: Individuals might recoup losses from bad investments.
3. Time management: People can recoup lost time by working more efficiently.
4. Energy: Athletes might need to recoup their strength after a tough match.
5. Legal contexts: Parties in a lawsuit might seek to recoup legal fees.
The term implies a process of getting back to a previous position or state, often after a loss or setback. It's generally viewed as a positive action, indicating resilience and recovery.

definition.Verb: 1. To breathe out air from the lungs. 2. To emit or give off (steam, fumes, etc.).

examples: Inhale deeply, then slowly exhale through your mouth.
The factory chimneys exhaled thick plumes of smoke into the sky.
further_explanation:
The word 'exhale' is commonly used in various contexts:
1. Physiology: It refers to the act of breathing out, which is part of the respiratory process.
2. Meditation and Yoga: Often used in instructions for breathing exercises.
3. Figurative use: Can mean to express relief or release tension, as in 'She exhaled her worries'.
4. Environmental: Describing the release of gases or vapors from objects or substances.
5. Emotional context: Sometimes used to describe releasing emotions, as in 'He exhaled his frustration'.
The term is often paired with its opposite, 'inhale', particularly in contexts related to breathing exercises or relaxation techniques.

definition.Verb: To breathe rapidly and with difficulty, typically due to exertion or excitement.
definition.Noun: The action of breathing rapidly and with difficulty.
definition.Adjective: Breathing rapidly and with difficulty.

examples: The dog was panting heavily after the long run.
We could hear the panting of the runners as they approached the finish line.
The panting athlete collapsed at the end of the marathon.
further_explanation:
The word 'panting' is used in various contexts:
1. Physical exertion: Often describes breathing after intense exercise or physical activity.
2. Animal behavior: Commonly used to describe how dogs regulate their body temperature through rapid breathing.
3. Medical context: Can indicate respiratory distress or other health issues.
4. Emotional states: Sometimes used to convey excitement, fear, or anxiety.
5. Literary use: May be used metaphorically to describe intense desire or eagerness.
Panting is characterized by quick, shallow breaths and is distinct from normal breathing or gasping. It's a natural response to increased oxygen demand or the need to cool down.

definition.Verb: To be or remain in a particular place, especially in a stealthy or secretive way.
definition.Adjective: Lying in wait, hidden, or concealed, especially with a threat or danger.

examples: The burglar was lurking in the shadows, waiting for the homeowners to leave.
The lurking danger of online scams is a constant concern for internet users.
further_explanation: The term 'lurking' is often used to describe a hidden, stealthy, or secretive presence or action. In the context of online communities, 'lurking' refers to the act of passively observing conversations or activities without actively participating. The adjective form 'lurking' emphasizes the sense of danger or threat that may be associated with something that is hidden or concealed.

definition.Noun: 1. The point at which two or more rivers or streams meet and join. 2. The act or process of merging, flowing, or coming together; the place of meeting.

examples: The confluence of the Yangtze and Jialing rivers is a major landmark in Chongqing.
The confluence of ideas and perspectives at the conference led to innovative solutions.
further_explanation:
The term 'confluence' is commonly used in both physical and figurative contexts:
1. Geography: Refers to the point where two or more rivers, streams, or other bodies of water meet and join together.
2. Figurative usage: Describes the merging or coming together of various elements, such as ideas, influences, or events.
In the geographical sense, the confluence is often an important location, as it can affect water flow, navigation, and ecosystem dynamics. In the figurative sense, the concept of confluence implies the integration or synthesis of different components into a unified whole.
The word is frequently used in discussions about urban planning, collaboration, and the interdisciplinary nature of various fields. Confluence can suggest a productive exchange of perspectives or the convergence of diverse elements to create something new.

definition.Noun: 1. A stock or store of money or valued objects, typically one that is secret or carefully guarded.
definition.Verb: 1. To accumulate (money or valued objects) and hide or store away.

examples: The archaeologists discovered a hoard of ancient coins buried in the field.
He tends to hoard old magazines and newspapers in his garage.
further_explanation: The word 'hoard' often implies collecting items in secret or keeping a large quantity of something for future use. This term is used both literally, such as hoarding food or money, and figuratively, such as hoarding information or emotions. In some cases, hoarding can have a negative connotation, suggesting an excessive or unreasonable accumulation of items.

definition.Noun: 1. The act of walking on the toes or on the balls of the feet, typically to avoid making noise.
definition.Verb: 1. To walk carefully and quietly on the tips of one's toes.
definition.Adverb: 1. In a manner that is quiet and careful, often to avoid detection.

examples: She had to tiptoe around the house so as not to wake the baby.
He was on tiptoe, trying to reach the book on the top shelf.
further_explanation: The term 'tiptoe' describes a delicate and careful movement, often associated with trying not to make noise or to avoid drawing attention. It can be used literally, as in walking lightly, or metaphorically, as in cautiously approaching a sensitive topic or situation.

translation: 抓住, 格斗, 努力解决

definition.Noun: 1. An act of wrestling or struggling, typically in a close and direct manner.
definition.Verb:
1. To engage in a close fight or struggle without weapons; to wrestle.
2. To struggle with or try to overcome a challenge or problem.

examples: The two wrestlers grappled for control in the ring.
She had to grapple with the complex issues presented by the project.
further_explanation: The word 'grapple' can be used both literally and figuratively. Literally, it refers to physical combat or wrestling, where two parties are locked in a close struggle. Figuratively, 'grapple' describes the process of confronting or dealing with a difficult situation or problem. The term suggests a hands-on, direct approach to overcoming obstacles or challenges.

definition.Noun: 1. A set of reasons or logical basis for a course of action, belief, or decision.

examples: The rationale behind the new policy was to improve workplace efficiency.
She explained the rationale for her decision to leave the company.
further_explanation: The word 'rationale' refers to the underlying reasoning or logic that justifies a particular action, belief, or decision. It often involves a careful analysis of the factors involved and is used to explain why something is done in a certain way. In discussions, the rationale is typically provided to give context or to persuade others of the validity of a choice.

translation: 构想, 想象, 怀孕

definition.Verb:
1. To form or develop an idea or plan in the mind.
2. To become pregnant with a child.
3. To understand or comprehend something.
4. To think of or consider something in a particular way.

examples: The engineer conceived a new design for the bridge.
They were overjoyed when they conceived their first child.
He couldn’t conceive how anyone could dislike chocolate.
She conceived of the project as a way to improve community relations.
further_explanation: The verb 'conceive' has multiple meanings that range from the abstract creation of ideas to the literal process of becoming pregnant. When you conceive an idea, you are forming it in your mind, often as a plan or concept. In a biological context, it refers to the beginning of pregnancy. The word can also be used to describe understanding something or viewing it in a certain way, highlighting its versatility in both everyday and specialized contexts.

definition.Noun: 1. A narrow channel dug in the ground, typically used for drainage alongside a road or field.
definition.Verb: 2. To get rid of something or abandon it; to leave someone suddenly or without explanation.

examples: The farmer dug a ditch around the field to improve drainage.
He decided to ditch his old phone and buy a new one.
further_explanation: The word 'ditch' can be used both as a noun and a verb. As a noun, it refers to a trench or narrow channel typically used for drainage purposes. As a verb, it means to abandon or get rid of something, or to leave someone suddenly. The verb form is often used in informal contexts, especially when talking about leaving someone or something abruptly.

definition.Noun: 1. A trick or device intended to attract attention, publicity, or business, often with little real value or substance.

examples: The company's latest marketing campaign was dismissed as a gimmick with no real innovation.
The store offered a free gift as a gimmick to entice customers.
further_explanation: A 'gimmick' is often used in a marketing or promotional context to refer to something designed to attract attention or interest but which may lack genuine value or substance. It can sometimes carry a negative connotation, implying that the gimmick is superficial or deceptive.

definition.Verb: 1. To completely remove or eliminate something, especially something harmful or undesirable.

examples: The government launched a campaign to eradicate illiteracy in rural areas.
Scientists are working hard to eradicate diseases like malaria.
further_explanation: The word 'eradicate' is often used in contexts where something harmful or undesirable is being completely removed or destroyed. It is a strong term implying thoroughness and permanence in the removal process.

definition.Adjective: 1. Relating to the Earth or land, as opposed to water or air. 2. Pertaining to the planet Earth as distinct from other planets or celestial bodies.

examples: The terrestrial environment includes forests, deserts, and grasslands.
Astronomers are searching for terrestrial planets that might support life.
further_explanation: The word 'terrestrial' is often used in contrast to aquatic (water-based) or celestial (space-related) contexts. It can describe anything related to land or the Earth, including animals, ecosystems, and even planets that are Earth-like.

definition.Noun: 1. Comfort or consolation in a time of distress.
definition.Verb: 2. To give comfort or consolation.

examples: He found solace in reading after the difficult day.
She solaced her friend in their time of need.
further_explanation: Solace is often sought in difficult times as a source of emotional relief. It can be found in various forms like activities, relationships, or simply time alone.

translation: 短暂的, 稍纵即逝的

definition.Adjective: 1. Lasting for a very short time.

examples: The fleeting moment of happiness passed quickly.
She caught a fleeting glimpse of the sunset.
further_explanation: The word 'fleeting' suggests something that is too brief to hold onto, often used to describe emotions, opportunities, or natural phenomena that quickly disappear.

definition.Noun: 1. A temporary relief or delay.
definition.Verb: 2. To postpone or cancel punishment.

examples: The prisoner received a reprieve just before the execution.
The company was reprieved from closure by an investor.
further_explanation: Reprieve is often used in legal contexts to refer to a delay in punishment. It can also be used more broadly to describe any temporary relief from an unpleasant situation.

definition.Noun: 1. The quality of being genuine or real.

examples: The painting was examined for authenticity.
Her authenticity in expressing her feelings was appreciated.
further_explanation: Authenticity relates to being true to oneself or to an original source. In various contexts, it implies honesty and adherence to fact or origin, as opposed to imitation or falsity.

definition.Noun: 1. The feeling that someone or something is unworthy of respect.
definition.Verb: 2. To regard or treat with contempt.

examples: He spoke of the proposal with disdain.
She disdained his offer of help.
further_explanation: Disdain is a strong term for an attitude of superiority or dismissal, often implying that something or someone is considered beneath one's dignity or worth.

definition.Noun: 1. A small partitioned space, often used in offices or public restrooms.

examples: She spent her workday in a small cubicle in the office.
The changing rooms are divided into individual cubicles.
further_explanation: Cubicles are often associated with office spaces, where individuals work in confined areas separated by partitions. They are also used in public restrooms, gyms, or changing rooms to provide privacy.

translation: 反抗, 蔑视, 挑战

definition.Verb: 1. To openly resist or refuse to obey.
2. To challenge or confront something with a sense of boldness.

examples: The protesters defied the government's orders.
She defied all expectations by succeeding in the task.
further_explanation: The word 'defy' is commonly used in situations where someone refuses to comply with authority or accepted norms, often with a sense of boldness or courage.

definition.Noun: 1. A person's posture or the position in which they stand, especially for sports or physical activity. 2. An attitude or position on a particular issue or topic.

examples: The politician's stance on climate change has gained a lot of attention.
His defensive stance helped him block the opponent's kick.
further_explanation: In sports, 'stance' refers to how someone positions their body for balance or performance. In a figurative sense, it reflects someone's opinion or position on a matter, often used in discussions of policy, politics, or debate.

definition.Verb: 1. To remain unaffected by or resist the force of something, especially pressure or hardship.

examples: The building was designed to withstand earthquakes.
She managed to withstand the criticism from her colleagues.
further_explanation: Withstand is often used in contexts where something is enduring a challenging or negative force. It emphasizes resilience and resistance.

definition.Verb: 1. To act in accordance with rules, standards, or requests.

examples: All companies must comply with the new safety regulations.
He complied with his parents' request to clean his room.
further_explanation: The word 'comply' is commonly used in legal, organizational, or social contexts where one adheres to rules or requests.

definition.Verb: 1. To wash something quickly with clean water to remove soap, dirt, or residue.
definition.Noun: 1. The act of washing something with clean water, especially to remove soap.

examples: After shampooing, rinse your hair thoroughly with water.
She gave the vegetables a quick rinse before cooking.
further_explanation: Rinse is commonly used in everyday contexts, particularly when referring to cleaning or washing something quickly. It often implies removing superficial dirt or residue rather than deep cleaning.

definition.Verb: 1. To supply water to something to maintain moisture levels. 2. To absorb water or fluid, often referring to the skin or body.

examples: It's important to hydrate your skin daily to keep it healthy.
Drinking plenty of water helps to hydrate the body.
further_explanation: Hydrate is commonly used in skincare, health, and science contexts, referring to the process of adding or maintaining moisture, whether in the body or external substances.

definition.Adjective: 1. Slightly wet or moist, often in an unpleasant way.
definition.Verb: 1. To make something slightly wet.
definition.Noun: 1. Moisture or humidity, especially in the air or on a surface.

examples: The damp clothes need more time to dry.
She damped the cloth to clean the table.
further_explanation: Damp often refers to slight moisture that is not fully wet but may feel unpleasant, such as in the air or on surfaces.

definition.Noun: 1. A tiny opening on the surface of the skin, or on the surface of plants, that allows fluids or gases to pass through.
definition.Verb: 1. To study or read something carefully or attentively (often used with 'over').

examples: The pores in her skin became more noticeable after exercising.
He pored over the old manuscripts for hours.
further_explanation: As a noun, 'pore' typically refers to small openings in biological surfaces. As a verb, it describes focusing intensely on reading or studying something.

definition.Noun: 1. Small, white cysts that form on the skin, typically around the eyes or cheeks, as a result of trapped keratin.

examples: Milia commonly appear in newborns but can also affect adults.
After the treatment, her milia gradually disappeared.
further_explanation: Milia are tiny skin bumps caused by trapped dead skin cells (keratin). They are harmless and often resolve on their own but may require treatment in some cases.

definition.Noun: 1. A small, natural indentation in the surface of something, especially in the skin, usually in the cheeks or chin.
definition.Verb: 2. To form or create a small dent or hollow, particularly in the skin.

examples: She had a cute dimple when she smiled.
The pebble dimpled the surface of the water.
further_explanation: Dimples are often seen as attractive features, particularly when they appear on the cheeks or chin during smiling. They can also form on other surfaces, like water.

definition.Verb:
1. To remove dead cells from the surface of the skin to make it smoother and clearer.
2. To shed layers or scales.

examples: You should exfoliate your skin once a week to maintain a smooth complexion.
The tree bark exfoliates naturally over time.
further_explanation: Exfoliation can refer to skincare routines where dead skin cells are removed, or natural processes like the shedding of bark or layers of a mineral.

definition.Noun: 1. A U.S. coin worth ten cents.

examples: He found a dime under the couch.
Prices haven't been this low since a dime could buy a meal.
further_explanation: The dime is the smallest and thinnest of all U.S. coins, widely recognized for its value of ten cents.

definition.Adjective: 1. (of a person's face or complexion) of an unhealthy yellow or pale brown color. 2. (of light) sickly or unpleasant in color.

examples: Years of working night shifts had given him a sallow complexion.
The sallow light of the fluorescent bulbs made everyone look ill.
further_explanation: The term 'sallow' primarily describes an unhealthy yellowish skin appearance, often indicating poor health or fatigue. It's used in health contexts, literary descriptions, to describe unpleasant lighting, and sometimes metaphorically for gloomy moods. The word implies a specific unhealthy hue, more precise than simply 'pale', and carries connotations of illness or poor living conditions.

definition.Noun: 1. The natural color, texture, and appearance of a person's skin, especially of the face. 2. The general aspect or character of something.

examples: She had a fair complexion that burned easily in the sun.
The economic complexion of the country changed dramatically after the new policies were implemented.
further_explanation: While primarily referring to skin appearance, 'complexion' can also metaphorically describe the overall character or aspect of a situation. It's used in beauty, health, and medical contexts to discuss skin health, and in broader contexts to describe the nature or character of abstract concepts or situations.

definition.Noun: Widespread destruction, damage, or disorder; chaos.

examples: The hurricane wreaked havoc on the coastal towns.
Computer viruses can wreak havoc on a company's network.
further_explanation: Often used with 'wreak' or 'play' (e.g., 'wreak havoc', 'play havoc'), the term emphasizes severe disruption or damage. It's used in various contexts, from natural disasters to personal life disruptions, conveying a sense of widespread and often uncontrollable negative impact.

translation: 造成，引起（尤指灾难性的后果）

definition.Verb: To cause or inflict (damage, harm, or vengeance), often with great force or intensity.

examples: The storm wreaked havoc on the coastal communities.
Her actions wreaked terrible consequences on the entire family.
further_explanation: Most commonly used in the phrase 'wreak havoc,' but can be used with other nouns like 'vengeance' or 'damage.' It implies a powerful and often destructive action, emphasizing the severe impact of the subject on its object.

definition.Noun: 1. The place where an event or meeting is happening. 2. (Law) The place where a case is heard in court.

examples: They chose a beautiful outdoor venue for their wedding ceremony.
The concert venue can accommodate up to 10,000 people.
further_explanation:
'Venue' is used in various contexts:
1. Events: Commonly refers to places where performances, sports events, or gatherings occur.
2. Legal: In law, it refers to the location where a case is heard.
3. Business: Often used for conference or meeting locations.
4. Sports: Describes stadiums or arenas where games are played.
5. Music: Refers to places where concerts or gigs are held.
The term implies a designated space for a specific purpose or event, often with considerations for capacity, facilities, and suitability for the intended use.

definition.Noun: The action of expelling someone, especially a tenant, from a property; the process of legally removing a tenant from a leased property.

examples: The landlord served an eviction notice to the tenants who hadn't paid rent in three months.
Many families faced eviction during the economic crisis.
further_explanation:
Eviction is a legal process typically used in housing contexts. It involves:
1. Landlord-tenant disputes: Often due to non-payment of rent or violation of lease terms.
2. Legal procedure: Requires proper notice and often court involvement.
3. Social issue: Can be controversial, especially during economic hardships.
4. Business context: Can refer to removing squatters from commercial properties.
5. Metaphorical use: Sometimes used figuratively to describe forced removal from non-housing situations.
Eviction can have significant social and economic impacts on individuals and communities.

definition.Noun: A mistaken belief, especially one based on unsound arguments; a failure in reasoning which renders an argument invalid.

examples: The idea that wealth always brings happiness is a common fallacy.
His argument contained several logical fallacies that weakened his position.
further_explanation:
The concept of 'fallacy' is crucial in critical thinking and logical reasoning:
1. In logic: Refers to a flaw in reasoning that makes an argument invalid.
2. In everyday use: Often describes widely held but false beliefs.
3. In debates: Identifying fallacies is a key skill in constructing and critiquing arguments.
4. Types of fallacies: Include ad hominem, straw man, false dichotomy, and many others.
5. In science: Fallacies can lead to incorrect conclusions and flawed theories.
6. In critical thinking: Understanding fallacies helps in developing stronger, more logical arguments.
Recognizing fallacies is an important skill in various fields, including philosophy, law, politics, and science.

definition.Adjective: 1. Perceptible by touch; able to be touched or felt. 2. Clear and definite; real.
definition.Noun: A thing that is perceptible by touch.

examples: The company wanted to see tangible results from their investment.
Her fear was almost tangible in the room.
further_explanation:
The word 'tangible' is used both literally and figuratively:
1. In a physical sense: It refers to things that can be touched or felt.
2. In business: Often used to describe measurable or quantifiable results.
3. In law: Tangible assets are physical items of value.
4. Figuratively: Used to describe things that are clear, definite, or real, even if not physical.
5. In contrast to 'intangible': Often used to distinguish between physical and non-physical assets or concepts.
The term generally implies something concrete and real, as opposed to abstract or theoretical.

definition.Verb: To imagine or picture in one's mind, especially a future event or situation.

examples: The architect envisioned a city with green spaces on every block.
I can't envision a world without the internet.
further_explanation:
'Envision' is often used in contexts involving future planning, creative thinking, or goal-setting. It implies a clear, detailed mental image or concept of something that doesn't yet exist or hasn't happened. The word is frequently used in:
1. Business: When discussing future strategies or developments.
2. Personal development: In setting and working towards personal goals.
3. Art and design: When conceptualizing new projects.
4. Politics and social change: When describing ideal future scenarios.
Envisioning is considered a powerful tool in various fields as it helps in setting clear objectives and working towards them.

definition.Verb: To reduce in quantity, content, or value; to use up or consume.

examples: Overuse of fossil fuels depletes our natural resources.
Stress can deplete your body's vitamins and minerals.
further_explanation: Often used in environmental, economic, and health contexts. It implies a gradual reduction or exhaustion of a finite resource or supply, emphasizing the idea of something being used up faster than it can be replenished or replaced.

definition.Verb: To restore friendly relations between; to cause to coexist in harmony; to make or show to be compatible.

examples: The couple sought counseling to reconcile their differences.
She struggled to reconcile her religious beliefs with scientific evidence.
further_explanation: Often used in contexts of conflict resolution, accounting, and personal relationships. It implies the process of finding a way to make different ideas, facts, or situations exist together without conflict, or to restore harmony between people after a disagreement.

definition.Noun: 1. Advice, especially that given formally. 2. A lawyer or group of lawyers giving legal advice and conducting cases in court.
definition.Verb: To give advice to someone, especially on how to solve a problem.

examples: She sought the counsel of her mentor before making a decision.
The defense counsel argued passionately for his client's innocence.
He counseled patience in dealing with the difficult situation.
further_explanation: The word 'counsel' has dual usage as both a noun and a verb. As a noun, it can refer to advice or to a legal professional. As a verb, it means to provide advice or guidance. It's commonly used in legal, professional, and personal contexts, often implying wisdom, experience, or expertise in the advice being given.

definition.Verb: 1. To bring back or re-establish (a previous right, practice, custom, or situation); to return (someone or something) to a former condition, place, or position. 2. To repair or renovate (a building, work of art, etc.) so as to return it to its original condition.

examples: The conservators worked tirelessly to restore the ancient painting.
The new government promised to restore democracy to the country.
After the power outage, technicians worked quickly to restore electricity to the affected areas.
further_explanation: The word 'restore' implies bringing something back to its original or former state. It's commonly used in contexts of conservation, renovation, computing (data restoration), health (restoring health or balance), and political or social change (restoring order or rights). The concept often carries a positive connotation, suggesting improvement or a return to a preferred state.

definition.Verb: To subject (someone) to hostility and ill-treatment, especially because of their race, political or religious beliefs, or sexual orientation.

examples: Throughout history, minority groups have often been persecuted by those in power.
The journalist was persecuted for exposing government corruption.
Many people fled the country to escape being persecuted for their religious beliefs.
further_explanation: The term 'persecute' implies a systematic mistreatment of an individual or group by another group. It often involves the abuse of power and is frequently used in contexts of human rights, religious freedom, and political oppression. The word carries strong negative connotations and implies unjust, cruel, or persistent action against others. It's distinct from 'prosecute,' which refers to instituting legal proceedings against someone.

definition.Noun: An idea or feeling that a word invokes in addition to its literal or primary meaning.

examples: The word 'home' has connotations of comfort and security.
In many cultures, the color white has connotations of purity and innocence.
The politician carefully chose words with positive connotations in his speech.
further_explanation: Connotation refers to the emotional or cultural associations that a word or phrase carries, beyond its literal definition. It's often contrasted with 'denotation,' which is the explicit or direct meaning of a word. Understanding connotations is crucial in effective communication, especially in writing, public speaking, and advertising, where the choice of words can significantly impact the message's reception. Connotations can vary across different cultures, contexts, and time periods.

definition.Noun: The act of treating someone badly, cruelly, or unfairly.

examples: The investigation revealed widespread mistreatment of workers in the factory.
Animal rights activists protested against the mistreatment of circus animals.
The patient filed a complaint alleging mistreatment by hospital staff.
further_explanation: Mistreatment encompasses a range of negative behaviors toward individuals or groups, including physical, emotional, or psychological abuse. It often implies a violation of rights, dignity, or well-being. The term is used in various contexts, including human rights, workplace issues, healthcare, animal welfare, and domestic situations. Mistreatment can be a single severe incident or a pattern of less severe but harmful actions over time. Addressing and preventing mistreatment is a key concern in many fields, including law, social work, and organizational management.

definition.Noun: 1. A movable joint or mechanism on which a door, gate, or lid swings as it opens and closes. 2. A central or pivotal point or principle on which everything depends.
definition.Verb: 1. To attach or be attached by or as if by a hinge. 2. To depend entirely on something.

examples: The old wooden door creaked on its rusty hinges.
The success of the project hinges on securing adequate funding.
She hinged the new cabinet doors carefully to ensure they aligned properly.
further_explanation: The word 'hinge' has both literal and figurative meanings. In its literal sense, it refers to a mechanical device that allows for rotational movement, commonly found in doors, gates, and lids. Metaphorically, it's used to describe a crucial point or factor on which something important depends or turns. This dual usage makes 'hinge' a versatile word in both practical and abstract contexts. In engineering and design, hinges are crucial components in various mechanisms. In everyday language, the phrase 'to hinge on' is often used to emphasize the critical nature of a particular factor in determining an outcome.

definition.Noun: 1. A sudden or forceful push. 2. The force that propels a jet or rocket engine. 3. The main point or gist of an argument or discussion.
definition.Verb: 1. To push or drive with force. 2. To force one's way into or through something. 3. To impose or inflict on someone.

examples: The rocket's powerful thrust propelled it into space.
He thrust the sword into the dragon's heart.
The main thrust of her argument was that education should be free for all.
The company is thrusting itself into new markets.
further_explanation: The word 'thrust' is versatile, used in physical, mechanical, and metaphorical contexts. In physics and engineering, it refers to a propulsive force, particularly in aviation and rocketry. In literature and rhetoric, it can describe forceful actions or the central idea of an argument. The verb form often implies sudden or forceful movement or action. In fencing and other martial arts, 'thrust' refers to a specific type of attack. The word's varied applications make it useful in technical discussions, creative writing, and everyday language, often conveying a sense of power, direction, or emphasis.

definition.Adverbial Phrase: Starting from the current moment or situation and continuing into the future; from now on.

examples: From this point onwards, all meetings will be held virtually.
The company decided to change its policy from this point onwards.
He vowed to eat healthier from this point onwards.
further_explanation: The phrase 'this point onwards' is commonly used to indicate a change or transition that begins at the present moment and continues into the future. It's often employed when announcing new policies, personal decisions, or shifts in behavior or processes. The phrase implies a clear demarcation between past practices and future intentions. It's frequently used in formal announcements, personal resolutions, and business communications to signify a change in direction or approach. The phrase can be modified to 'from this point onwards' or 'from this point forward' without significant change in meaning. In legal or very formal contexts, synonyms like 'henceforth' or 'hereinafter' might be preferred.

definition.Verb: 1. To struggle to move or obtain footing; to stumble clumsily. 2. To have difficulty doing something; to proceed or act clumsily or ineffectively.
definition.Noun: A type of flatfish that lives on the seabed, typically having both eyes on one side of the head.

examples: The new employee floundered as he tried to understand the complex filing system.
The company floundered for years before finally going bankrupt.
We caught several flounders while fishing off the pier.
She floundered through the deep snow, struggling to make progress.
further_explanation: The word 'flounder' has distinct meanings as a verb and a noun. As a verb, it metaphorically draws from the fish's awkward movement on land, describing clumsy or ineffective actions, often in situations where one is out of their depth literally or figuratively. It's commonly used to describe struggling businesses, confused individuals, or anyone having difficulty in a challenging situation. As a noun, it refers to a specific type of flatfish, known for its distinctive appearance with both eyes on one side of its head. The verb usage is more common in everyday language, often employed in business, educational, or personal contexts to describe struggles or ineffectiveness. The dual meaning of 'flounder' makes it a potential source of wordplay in creative writing.

definition.Noun: The confidence, enthusiasm, and discipline of a person or group at a particular time; a sense of common purpose with respect to a group.

examples: The team's morale was high after their recent string of victories.
Employee morale suffered due to the announcement of impending layoffs.
The general sought to boost the troops' morale before the battle.
Good leadership is crucial for maintaining high morale in any organization.
further_explanation: Morale is a critical concept in organizational psychology, military contexts, and team management. It refers to the mental and emotional state of an individual or group, particularly in relation to their confidence, optimism, and willingness to perform tasks or face challenges. High morale is often associated with increased productivity, better teamwork, and resilience in the face of adversity. Conversely, low morale can lead to decreased performance, higher turnover rates, and a negative work atmosphere. Factors that can affect morale include leadership quality, work environment, recognition and rewards, job security, and group dynamics. In military contexts, morale is considered crucial for combat effectiveness. The term is also used in sports to describe a team's collective spirit and determination. Managers and leaders often focus on strategies to boost and maintain morale as a key aspect of organizational success.

definition.Noun: 1. A pair of fetters connected together by a chain, used to fasten a prisoner's wrists or ankles together. 2. A device used to secure or fasten, such as a bolt or padlock.
definition.Verb: 1. To restrain with shackles. 2. To restrict or impede the freedom or progress of.

examples: The prisoner's ankles were bound with iron shackles.
Outdated regulations can shackle innovation and progress.
He felt shackled by his responsibilities and unable to pursue his dreams.
The ship's crew used a shackle to secure the anchor chain.
further_explanation: The word 'shackle' has both literal and metaphorical meanings. In its literal sense, it refers to physical restraints, often used in law enforcement or historical contexts of imprisonment. These can be metal fasteners for the wrists or ankles, or nautical equipment for securing ropes or chains. Metaphorically, 'shackle' is widely used to describe anything that restricts freedom, progress, or movement, whether it's rules, obligations, or societal expectations. This figurative use often appears in discussions about personal freedom, social justice, or economic policy. The verb form 'to shackle' can describe the act of physically restraining someone, but more commonly it's used figuratively to mean imposing restrictions or limitations. In engineering and construction, shackles are important connecting devices, highlighting the word's diverse applications across different fields. The enduring use of 'shackle' in both concrete and abstract senses makes it a powerful word in literature, politics, and everyday language to convey ideas of constraint and limitation.

definition.Noun: 1. A fierce or destructive attack. 2. A large quantity of people or things that appear or arrive suddenly.

examples: The army prepared for the enemy's onslaught at dawn.
The company's website crashed under the onslaught of Black Friday shoppers.
He faced an onslaught of criticism after his controversial statement.
The coastline suffered severe erosion from the onslaught of hurricanes.
further_explanation: The word 'onslaught' carries a strong connotation of intensity and often implies a sense of being overwhelmed. Originally a military term describing a violent attack, its usage has broadened to include any situation where someone or something faces a sudden, intense, and often overwhelming force or challenge. In modern usage, 'onslaught' is frequently employed metaphorically to describe non-violent but intense experiences, such as information overload, severe weather, or a flood of emotions. It's particularly effective in conveying a sense of relentlessness or inevitability. The term is common in journalism to describe natural disasters, public reactions, or market forces. In business contexts, it might describe aggressive competition or rapid technological change. The word's forceful sound and meaning make it a powerful choice in rhetoric and creative writing, often used to create a sense of drama or urgency. While primarily used as a noun, it can sometimes be found in phrases like 'to launch an onslaught,' where it takes on a more active role.

definition.Verb: 1. To make or become stiff or rigid. 2. To make or become more severe, harsh, or difficult. 3. To strengthen one's resolve; to become more determined.

examples: The cold wind made his fingers stiffen.
Her expression stiffened when she heard the bad news.
The government stiffened the penalties for drunk driving.
He stiffened his resolve and prepared to face the challenge.
further_explanation: The verb 'stiffen' primarily describes a physical process of becoming more rigid or less flexible, but it has expanded to include several metaphorical uses. In its literal sense, it often refers to physical objects or body parts becoming less pliable due to factors like cold, age, or chemical processes. Metaphorically, it can describe emotional or mental states, typically indicating a hardening of attitude or increased determination. In social or political contexts, 'stiffening' can refer to making rules, laws, or punishments more severe. The word is also used in technical fields: in engineering, materials might be stiffened to increase their strength; in cooking, certain ingredients stiffen mixtures. The phrase 'to stiffen one's resolve' is a common idiom meaning to become more determined. In body language, a person 'stiffening' often indicates surprise, fear, or increased alertness. The versatility of 'stiffen' makes it useful in various contexts, from describing physical changes to conveying subtle shifts in emotion or policy.

definition.Verb: 1. To apply or put forth (effort, influence, pressure, etc.). 2. To use (strength, ability, or power) in order to achieve something.

examples: She had to exert all her strength to lift the heavy box.
The leader exerted considerable influence over the decision-making process.
further_explanation: The verb 'exert' is commonly used when talking about applying effort, force, or influence to achieve a particular result. It often implies a significant or focused effort.

definition.Noun: 1. A plantation of grapevines, typically for wine production.

examples: The vineyard produced an excellent vintage this year.
We took a tour of the vineyards in Napa Valley.
further_explanation: Vineyards are usually associated with the production of wine and are located in regions with climates favorable to grape cultivation. The term can also refer to the business of producing wine.

definition.Noun: 1. A piece of land planted with fruit trees.

examples: The apple orchard was in full bloom during the spring.
They own an orchard that produces peaches and cherries.
further_explanation: Orchards are areas of land where fruit trees are grown for commercial purposes. Common fruits produced in orchards include apples, pears, peaches, and cherries.

definition.Noun: 1. A period of suspended development in an insect, fish, or other animal, especially during unfavorable environmental conditions.

examples: Insects enter diapause to survive through winter when food is scarce.
The diapause phase can be triggered by changes in temperature or day length.
further_explanation: Diapause is a survival strategy in animals where their development is temporarily halted until conditions become favorable again. It is most commonly observed in insects and is similar to hibernation.

definition.Verb: 1. To spend the winter in a dormant state, typically in animals like bears and bats.

examples: Bears hibernate in caves during the cold winter months.
Some animals hibernate to conserve energy when food is scarce.
further_explanation: Hibernation is a state of inactivity and metabolic depression in animals during winter. It helps them survive periods of cold temperatures and food scarcity by significantly slowing down their bodily functions.

definition.Noun: 1. A distinctive, typically pleasant smell.

examples: The aroma of freshly baked bread filled the kitchen.
The coffee shop was known for its rich aroma.
further_explanation: Aroma generally refers to the pleasant and distinctive smell associated with food, beverages, or natural substances. It is often used to describe the scent of coffee, wine, flowers, and other fragrant items.

definition.Verb: 1. To emerge from an egg, chrysalis, or pupa.
definition.Noun: 2. An opening in a floor, ceiling, or roof, typically with a door or cover.

examples: The chicks began to hatch after three weeks of incubation.
He climbed through the hatch in the roof to access the attic.
further_explanation: As a verb, 'hatch' refers to the process of an animal emerging from an egg. As a noun, it can refer to an opening, usually in a structure, through which access is gained.

definition.Verb: 1. To become fully developed or mature, particularly in reference to fruit or crops.

examples: The tomatoes will ripen more quickly in the warm sunlight.
They waited for the grapes to ripen before harvesting.
further_explanation: Ripen refers to the process by which fruits, vegetables, or other crops reach a stage where they are ready to be harvested or eaten, often characterized by a change in color, texture, and taste.

definition.Verb: 1. To become fully developed or mature, particularly in reference to fruit or crops.

examples: The tomatoes will ripen more quickly in the warm sunlight.
They waited for the grapes to ripen before harvesting.
further_explanation: Ripen refers to the process by which fruits, vegetables, or other crops reach a stage where they are ready to be harvested or eaten, often characterized by a change in color, texture, and taste.

definition.Phrasal Verb: 1. To carefully question or seek information from someone in order to discover their views or opinions about something.

examples: She decided to sound out her colleagues before making any big decisions.
He sounded out the investors to gauge their interest in the new project.
further_explanation: The phrase 'sound out' is commonly used to describe discreet or informal efforts to explore someone's opinion or intentions. It typically implies a cautious or indirect approach in seeking information, often done to avoid committing to a decision too soon. It is frequently used in business, politics, or personal situations where gauging reactions without fully revealing one's position is crucial.

definition.Verb: 1. To act as an intermediary in a conflict or dispute to bring about an agreement or reconciliation. 2. To intervene in a process or situation.

examples: The lawyer was asked to mediate between the two parties.
She successfully mediated the discussion, ensuring both sides were heard.
further_explanation: To 'mediate' means to step in as a neutral party to help resolve a dispute or disagreement. The role of a mediator is not to make decisions but to facilitate communication and find common ground between conflicting sides.

definition.Verb: 1. To remove people from a dangerous area or situation for safety. 2. To empty an area or building for safety reasons.

examples: The city was ordered to evacuate due to the approaching hurricane.
Firefighters helped to evacuate the building after the fire broke out.
further_explanation: The term 'evacuate' is often used in emergency contexts, such as during natural disasters or dangerous situations, where people or animals need to be removed from a specific area for safety. It can also refer to emptying a space.

definition.Verb: 1. To supervise or manage an activity, project, or group of people to ensure that tasks are completed properly.

examples: The manager was hired to oversee the construction project.
She oversees the daily operations of the company.
further_explanation: To 'oversee' involves supervising or watching over tasks, ensuring they are done according to plan. It often applies to leadership roles in managing processes or teams.

definition.Verb: 1. To destroy completely or wipe out. 2. To defeat overwhelmingly in a competition or conflict.

examples: The explosion annihilated the entire city.
Their team was annihilated in the championship game.
further_explanation: The term 'annihilate' suggests total destruction or eradication, often in a violent or overwhelming manner. It can be used in both literal and metaphorical contexts.

translation: 争抢, 攀爬, 仓促行动

definition.Verb: 1. To move or climb quickly using hands and feet. 2. To mix or jumble things together in a hurried or disorganized way. 3. To make something (like signals) unclear to prevent unauthorized understanding.
definition.Noun: 1. A hurried or disorganized struggle or action.

examples: She scrambled over the rocks.
He scrambled to get ready for the meeting.
The eggs were scrambled with vegetables.
further_explanation: The verb 'scramble' is often used in both physical and figurative senses, indicating quick, often disorganized movement or action. It can also refer to mixing or jamming things together hastily, or in technology, scrambling signals to secure data.

definition.Noun: 1. Soldiers who fight on foot, typically the main land-based component of an army.

examples: The infantry advanced steadily across the battlefield.
He served in the infantry during the war.
further_explanation: The word 'infantry' refers to a branch of an army primarily composed of soldiers trained to fight on foot. Unlike other units like cavalry or artillery, infantry focuses on ground combat and close engagement with the enemy.

definition.Verb: 1. To fall behind or move or respond more slowly than expected.
definition.Noun: 1. A delay or period of time between one event or process and another.

examples: The project is lagging behind schedule.
There is a lag between cause and effect in economic policies.
further_explanation: The term 'lag' can describe both physical delays (such as a person moving slowly) and technical delays (as seen in digital processing or networks).

translation: 完整无缺的, 未受损的

definition.Adjective: 1. Not damaged or impaired; remaining whole and complete.

examples: Despite the storm, the building remained intact.
The ancient manuscript was discovered intact in the ruins.
further_explanation: The adjective 'intact' describes something that has not been harmed or altered and remains in its original condition. It is often used for physical objects but can apply to abstract things like reputations or relationships.

definition.Noun: 1. A small mark or flaw that spoils the appearance of something. 2. A moral defect or fault.
definition.Verb: To spoil or damage the appearance or quality of something.

examples: The antique vase would be perfect if not for the small blemish on its surface.
His otherwise spotless career was marred by a single blemish.
The harsh detergent blemished the delicate fabric.
She tried to cover the blemish on her cheek with makeup.
further_explanation: The word 'blemish' is versatile, applying to both physical and abstract concepts. In its physical sense, it often refers to a visible mark or imperfection that detracts from the appearance of something, commonly used in contexts of skin care, product quality, or aesthetics. Metaphorically, it extends to moral or reputational imperfections, describing a flaw in character, behavior, or record. In professional settings, a 'blemish on one's record' suggests a minor but noteworthy negative incident in an otherwise positive history. The term is prevalent in industries where appearance is crucial, such as cosmetics, manufacturing, and agriculture (for produce quality). In art and antiques, blemishes can significantly affect value. The verb form 'to blemish' implies causing damage, often unintentionally, to something's appearance or reputation. The concept of 'blemish-free' is often used as a standard of perfection in various fields. The word's use can range from everyday contexts (like skin blemishes) to more formal or literary applications describing flaws in abstract concepts like honor or perfection.

definition.Adjective: Made as a final attempt to achieve something after other attempts have failed; desperate and undertaken only as a last resort.

examples: The company made a last-ditch effort to avoid bankruptcy by seeking new investors.
In a last-ditch attempt to pass the exam, he stayed up all night studying.
The defense lawyer presented a last-ditch argument to sway the jury.
Scientists are making last-ditch attempts to save the endangered species from extinction.
further_explanation: The phrase 'last-ditch' originates from military terminology, where a 'last ditch' referred to the final line of defense. It has since evolved into a widely used idiomatic expression describing a final, often desperate attempt to solve a problem or achieve a goal. The term carries connotations of urgency, desperation, and being at the end of one's resources or options. It's commonly used in various contexts, including business (e.g., last-ditch negotiations), politics (last-ditch efforts to pass legislation), sports (a team's last-ditch attempt to win), and personal endeavors. The phrase often implies that the attempt being described is unlikely to succeed, but is being made anyway as there are no other options left. It's frequently paired with words like 'effort,' 'attempt,' or 'try.' In storytelling and media, a 'last-ditch effort' often creates tension and drama. While primarily used as an adjective, it can sometimes function as an adverb in phrases like 'fighting last-ditch.' The term's dramatic quality makes it a favorite in news headlines and narrative descriptions of critical situations.

definition.Adverb: 1. Without intention; accidentally. 2. In a manner characterized by lack of attention or care.

examples: He inadvertently offended his colleague with his poorly worded email.
The classified information was inadvertently leaked to the press.
further_explanation: The term 'inadvertently' is derived from the adjective 'inadvertent', which is the opposite of 'advertent'. It's commonly used to describe actions or consequences that occur without the person's conscious intention or awareness. This word is often used in formal contexts, such as in business communications or legal documents, to emphasize that an action was not deliberate. It can be particularly important in situations where intent matters, such as in legal cases or when discussing mistakes in professional settings.

definition.Noun: 1. A state of balance between opposing forces or influences. 2. A state of physical balance. 3. A state of mental or emotional stability or composure.

examples: The ecosystem maintains a delicate equilibrium between predators and prey.
After the economic shock, the market took months to return to equilibrium.
The gymnast maintained perfect equilibrium on the balance beam.
further_explanation: The concept of 'equilibrium' is crucial in many fields, including physics, chemistry, economics, and psychology. In physics, it refers to a system where the net force acting on it is zero. In chemistry, it describes a reversible reaction in which the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. Economists use the term to describe a state where economic forces are balanced. In psychology, it can refer to emotional stability or Piaget's theory of cognitive development. The word comes from Latin 'aequilibrium', meaning 'equal balance'.

definition.Adjective: 1. Famous or well-known, typically for some bad quality or deed.

examples: The city is notorious for its high crime rate.
He became notorious after the scandal was made public.
further_explanation: Notorious is often used to describe a negative reputation or fame, typically linked to criminal activities, scandals, or undesirable traits.

definition.Adjective: 1. Acting or done without careful consideration of the possible consequences.
definition.Noun: 2. A spotty area of irritated or inflamed skin.

examples: It was a rash decision to invest all the money in one company.
She developed a rash after using the new skincare product.
further_explanation: As an adjective, rash refers to making hasty decisions without thinking through consequences. As a noun, it describes a skin condition.

definition.Verb: 1. To make someone ecstatically happy or filled with joy.

examples: Winning the award elated her beyond words.
He was elated after hearing the good news.

definition.Noun: 1. A group of vehicles or ships traveling together, typically accompanied by armed troops for protection.
definition.Verb: 1. To accompany or escort, typically for protection.

examples: A military convoy passed through the town.
The ships were convoyed across the ocean.

definition.Adjective: 1. Extremely large or great in size or degree.

examples: The building was of immense proportions.
She felt immense relief after finishing the exam.

definition.Verb: 1. To cause something or someone to change direction or focus.

examples: The police diverted traffic to avoid the accident site.
She tried to divert attention from her mistake.

definition.Verb: 1. To gather into a crowd or group.

examples: People began to congregate in the town square.
Students congregated outside the auditorium.

definition.Adjective: 1. Of vital importance; crucial.
definition.Noun: 1. A command or order.

examples: It is imperative that we address this issue immediately.
The doctor gave an imperative to rest.

definition.Noun: 1. Serious and immediate danger.

examples: The hikers were in great peril as the storm approached.
They underestimated the peril of crossing the river.

definition.Adjective: 1. Firmly established and difficult to change.

examples: The company has an entrenched culture of innovation.
His views on politics are deeply entrenched.

definition.Noun: 1. An excessive supply of a product, leading to lower prices and reduced profitability.

examples: The oil industry is facing a supply glut.
A supply glut of smartphones has driven prices down.

definition.Noun: 1. Severe suffering or deprivation.

examples: The war caused unimaginable hardship for civilians.
They endured many hardships during the economic downturn.

definition.Noun: 1. The state of not moving or flowing, leading to lack of development or progress.

examples: Economic stagnation is a concern for policymakers.
There was a period of cultural stagnation in the country.

definition.Verb: 1. To suppress or hold back; to prevent from developing freely.

examples: Her creativity was stifled by strict rules.
The company stifled competition by acquiring smaller businesses.

definition.Adjective: 1. Something that is harsh, oppressive, and relentless.

examples: They lived in grinding poverty.
The project involved grinding work that seemed never-ending.

definition.Adjective: 1. Willing to adjust to others' needs; flexible in approach.

examples: The central bank's accommodative policy supported economic growth.
She was very accommodative to the needs of her team.

definition.Adjective: 1. Quiet, reflective, or restrained.

examples: The atmosphere was subdued after the announcement.
She spoke in a subdued tone during the meeting.

definition.Phrase: 1. Indicating a particular development or change.

examples: In a sign of recovery, the economy grew by 2%.
In a sign of trust, he gave her access to his personal files.

definition.Verb: 1. Falling or dropping sharply.

examples: The stock market is plummeting after the announcement.
Temperatures are plummeting as winter approaches.

definition.Verb: 1. To reduce something dramatically or severely.

examples: The company slashed its prices to boost sales.
Funding for the project was slashed by 50%.

definition.Adjective: 1. Tending to remind one of something or evoking memories of the past.

examples: The music was reminiscent of the 1980s.
Her style is reminiscent of classic Hollywood actresses.

definition.Noun: 1. A child, often used in a derogatory way to refer to a spoiled or rude child.

examples: He's such a brat; he always wants his way.
The brat threw a tantrum when he didn't get the toy.

definition.Verb: 1. To arouse curiosity or interest; to fascinate.
definition.Noun: 1. A secret plan or scheme; the act of plotting.

examples: The story intrigued her from the beginning.
The novel was filled with political intrigue.

definition.Noun: 1. An agreement between warring parties to stop fighting temporarily.

examples: The armistice was signed after months of negotiation.
Both sides agreed to an armistice to allow for peace talks.

definition.Adjective: 1. Able to be copied or reproduced.

examples: The experiment yielded replicable results across different labs.
They designed a replicable process for others to follow.

definition.Adjective: 1. Temporary or provisional; for the time being.
definition.Noun: 1. An intervening time or period.

examples: He took on the role of interim manager until a permanent one was found.
In the interim, we will continue with our current strategy.

definition.Noun: 1. An arrangement with a bank that allows an account holder to withdraw more money than they have in their account.

examples: He was charged a fee for exceeding his overdraft limit.
Using an overdraft can help in emergencies, but it can lead to debt.

definition.Verb: 1. To express disapproval of something; to belittle or disparage.

examples: She deprecated his casual attitude toward the project.
Many experts deprecated the use of outdated methods.

definition.Verb: 1. To deprive of air or oxygen; to choke.

examples: The smoke began to suffocate everyone in the room.
He felt suffocated by the intense pressure of expectations.

definition.Verb: 1. To jab or prod someone or something with a finger or object.

examples: He poked her in the ribs to get her attention.
The cat poked its head out from behind the curtain.

definition.Noun: 1. A localized physical condition characterized by redness, swelling, heat, and pain, often as a response to injury or infection.

examples: The doctor diagnosed her with inflammation in her knee.
Inflammation can occur as a response to allergens or irritants.

definition.Noun: 1. The skin covering the head, excluding the face, which contains hair follicles.

examples: She massaged her scalp to relieve tension.
Dandruff can be a common issue affecting the scalp.

definition.Verb: 1. To block or become blocked, preventing movement or flow.
definition.Noun: 1. A blockage or obstruction.

examples: The drain was clogged with hair and soap scum.
She used a solution to unclog the sink.

definition.Adjective: 1. Covered with or resembling grease; oily.

examples: His hands were greasy after working on the car.
The pizza left a greasy residue on the plate.

definition.Noun: 1. A thick liquid used for moisturizing or treating the skin.

examples: She applied lotion to her dry skin after the shower.
Sunscreen is a type of lotion that protects against UV rays.

definition.Noun: 1. A thick, sticky, or dirty substance; mess.

examples: There was a lot of gunk built up in the corners of the room.
The car's engine was covered in greasy gunk.

definition.Adjective: 1. Referring to products that are formulated to not clog pores.

examples: Choose noncomedogenic makeup to avoid acne breakouts.
Many skincare brands offer noncomedogenic options.

definition.Verb: 1. To form a mass of small bubbles or foam by agitating a substance in water.
definition.Noun: 1. A mass of bubbles produced by soap or detergent.

examples: Lather the shampoo into your hair for best results.
The soap created a rich lather that smelled wonderful.
